### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)

   |
12 |     IsBST(right, value, upper)
   |                               ^

ex.dfy(12,30): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['    IsBST(right, value, upper)\n']

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true

   |
13 |   case Empty => true
   |                     ^

              | Empty

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers

              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree

Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.

              | Empty

{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (value < v) ? Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)

    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true

  reads t
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t

Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
  reads t
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)

   |
25 |   case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
   |                                          ^

ex.dfy(25,41): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE

['  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)\n']

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers

              | Empty

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true

function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
  requires IsBST(t, 0, nat.MaxInt)

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
  requires IsBST(t, 0, nat.MaxInt)
{

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{

   |
18 | {
   |  ^

              | Empty

predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)

Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).

Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

  case Node(left, value, right) =>

Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.

datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)

              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

{
  match t

    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value ? Contains(left, v) : Contains(right, v))

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers

              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&

    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)

{

    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)

Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof is by structural recursion on the tree
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false

              | Empty

predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof is by structural recursion on the tree
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof is by structural recursion on the tree and case analysis on the result of Insert
}

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>

  case Empty => false

  // Proof is by structural recursion on the tree

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion

SCORE
1.0
['// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion\n']
TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2

### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)

              | Empty

ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)

              | Empty

{

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value {
      InsertMaintainsIsBST(left, v, lower, value);

   |
51 |       InsertMaintainsIsBST(left, v, lower, value);
   |                                                   ^

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value {
      InsertMaintainsIsBST(left, v, lower, value);
    } else if v > value {

   |
52 |     } else if v > value {
   |                          ^

              | Empty

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value then

   |
50 |     if v < value then
   |                  ^

ex.dfy(50,17): Error: lbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['    if v < value then\n']
TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value then
      InsertMaintainsIsBST(left, v, lower, value)

   |
50 |     if v < value then
   |                  ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value then
      InsertMaintainsIsBST(left, v, lower, value)
    else if v > value then

   |

   |                  ^

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
}

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
}

ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{

              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)

  case Node(left, value, right) =>

    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)

}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false

datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)

SCORE
1.0
['ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)\n']
TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers

              | Empty

    IsBST(right, value, upper)

}

    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true

function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false

ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value then
      InsertMaintainsBST(left, v, lower, value)

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value then
      InsertMaintainsBST(left, v, lower, value)
    else if v > value then

   |

   |                  ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
}
``` import React from 'react'

   | ^

   |     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t

   |
41 |   // Proof by structural induction on t
   |                                        ^

              | Empty

    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers

              | Empty

predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

    // Case 1: v < value

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value

   |

   |                         ^

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value
    else if v > value {

   |
49 |     else if v > value {
   |                        ^

ex.dfy(49,23): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE

['    else if v > value {\n']

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value
    else if v > value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
    }
  case Empty =>
    // Base case: v = value
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)

TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value
    else if v > value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
    }
  case Empty =>
    // Base case: v = value
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)

SCORE
1.0
['requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)\n']
TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value
    else if v > value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
    }
  case Empty =>
    // Base case: v = value
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)

SCORE
1.0
['ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)\n']

    // Base case: v = value

              | Empty

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true

{

    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)

{

    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))

    // Base case: v = value

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value
    else if v > value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
    }
  case Empty =>
    // Base case: v = value
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value
    else if v > value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
    }
  case Empty =>
    // Base case: v = value
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);

   |
66 |       InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
   |                                                 ^

ex.dfy(66,48): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE

['      InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);\n']

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value
    else if v > value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
    }
  case Empty =>
    // Base case: v = value
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
    }

   |
67 |     }
   |      ^
