```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value
    else if v > value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
    }
  case Empty =>
    // Base case: v = value
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion

requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers

              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))

}

    // Base case: v = value
}

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers

              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))

}

      InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value

      InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
    }
  case Empty =>
    // Base case: v = value
}

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))

}

      InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value

      InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
    }
  case Empty =>
    // Base case: v = value
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion

requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{

    // Case 1: v < value

      InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value

    // Base case: v = value

datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value
    else if v > value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
    }
  case Empty =>
    // Base case: v = value
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value
    else if v > value {
      InsertPreservesBST(right, v, value, upper);
    }
  case Empty =>
    // Base case: v = value

   |
73 |     // Base case: v = value
   |                            ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.

Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form

case Foo(x, y) => 1

### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value
    else if v > value {
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
    }
  case Empty =>
    // Base case: v = value
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    // Case 1: v < value
    if v < value {
      InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
    }
    // Case 2: v > value
    else if v > value {
      InsertPreservesBST(right, v, value, upper);
    }
  case Empty =>
    // Base case: v = value
}

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)

Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)

SCORE
1.0
['lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)\n']

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}


SCORE

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers

              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree

    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&

    IsBST(right, value, upper)

  case Node(left, value, right) =>

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false

    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))

  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{

    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);

}

  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);

   |
56 |     InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
   |                                               ^

Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
    InsertPreservesBST(right, v, value, upper);

   |                                                ^

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element

  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
    InsertPreservesBST(right, v, value, upper);

              | Empty

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
    InsertPreservesBST(right, v, value, upper);
  case Empty =>
}
```

              | Empty

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element

{

    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.

Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.

case Foo(x, y) => 1

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
    InsertPreservesBST(right, v, value, upper);
  case Empty =>
}

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
    InsertPreservesBST(right, v, value, upper);
  case Empty =>
}

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element

  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t

    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

              | Empty

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value then

   |

   |                  ^

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value then
      InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);

   |                  ^

              | Empty

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true

  case Node(left, value, right) =>

{
  match t

    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
    InsertPreservesBST(right, v, value, upper);
  case Empty =>

   |

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
    InsertPreservesBST(right, v, value, upper);
  case Empty =>
}

```dafny

              | Empty

predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))

              | Empty

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))

  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
    InsertPreservesBST(right, v, value, upper);
  case Empty =>
}

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)

SCORE
1.0
['  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)\n']

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.

Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false

{

    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>

  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertPreservesIsBST(left, v, lower, value);
    InsertPreservesIsBST(right, v, value, upper);
  case Empty =>

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertPreservesIsBST(left, v, lower, value);
    InsertPreservesIsBST(right, v, value, upper);
  case Empty =>
}

              | Empty

predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true

{

    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))

    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))

              | Empty

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true

}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value {
      InsertPreservesIsBST(left, v, lower, value);

   |
57 |       InsertPreservesIsBST(left, v, lower, value);
   |                                                   ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value {
      InsertPreservesIsBST(left, v, lower, value);
    } else if v > value {

  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value then

   |                  ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value then
      InsertPreservesIsBST(left, v, lower, value);

   |
56 |     if v < value then
   |                  ^

ex.dfy(56,17): Error: lbrace expected
   |
57 |       InsertPreservesIsBST(left, v, lower, value);
   |                                                   ^

ex.dfy(57,50): Error: rbrace expected
2 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['      InsertPreservesIsBST(left, v, lower, value);\n']

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
  case Empty =>
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesIsBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the input tree t
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value then
      InsertPreservesIsBST(left, v, lower, value);
    else if v > value then

   |

   |                  ^

  reads t
{

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    if v < value then
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, v)

   |
43 |     if v < value then
   |                  ^

ex.dfy(43,17): Error: lbrace expected
   |
44 |       InsertEnsuresContains(left, v)
   |                                     ^

ex.dfy(44,36): Error: invalid UpdateStmt
2 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.

case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element

{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false

  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{

              | Empty

    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false

  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)

    case Node(left, value, right) =>
      if v == value {

        InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Base cases
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    match t
    case Node(left, value, right) =>
      if v == value {
      } else if v < value {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
      } else {

   |

   |               ^
