```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Base cases
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    match t
    case Node(left, value, right) =>
      if v == value {
      } else if v < value {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
      } else {
        InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
      }
  }
}

lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Base cases
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    match t
    case Node(left, value, right) =>
      if v == value {
      } else if v < value {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
      } else {
        InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
      }
  }
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)

SCORE
1.0
['  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)\n']
TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Base cases
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    match t
    case Node(left, value, right) =>
      if v == value {
      } else if v < value {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
      } else {
        InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
      }
  }
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)

SCORE
1.0
['  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)\n']
TEXT

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element

  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Base cases

  } else {
    match t

      if v == value {
      } else if v < value {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
      } else {
        InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
      }
  }
}

  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Base cases
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    match t
    case Node(left, value, right) =>
      if v == value {
      } else if v < value {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
      } else {
        InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
      }
  }
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Base cases
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    match t
    case Node(left, value, right) =>
      if v < value {
        InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);

   |
65 |         InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
   |                                                   ^

              | Empty

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)

{

    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))

      }

  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Base cases
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    match t
    case Node(left, value, right) =>
      if v == value {
      } else if v < value {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
      } else {
        InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
      }
  }
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Base cases
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    match t
    case Node(left, value, right) =>
      if v == value {
      } else if v < value {

   |

   |                            ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Base cases
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    match t
    case Node(left, value, right) =>
      if v == value {
      } else if v < value {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
      } else {
        InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
      }
  }
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{

              | Empty

    value <= upper &&

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Base cases
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    match t
    case Node(left, value, right) =>
      if v == value {
      } else if v < value {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
      } else {
        InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
      }
  }
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Base cases
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    match t
    case Node(left, value, right) =>
      if v < value {
        InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);
      } else if v > value {

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.

Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate that checks if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat) 
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)
  case Empty => Node(Empty, v, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, v: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
{
  // Base cases
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    match t
    case Node(left, value, right) =>
      if v == value {
      } else if v < value {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
      } else {
        InsertEnsuresContains(right, v);
      }
  }
}

// (6) Define a lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesBST(t: Tree, v: nat, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  requires IsBST(t, lower, upper)
  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)
{
  // Base cases

  } else {
    match t

      } else if v > value {

              | Empty

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    (if v < value then Node(Insert(left, v), value, right)
    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)

{

    (v == value) || (v < value && Contains(left, v)) || (v > value && Contains(right, v))

  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)

      if v == value {
      } else if v < value {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, v);
      } else {

      }
  }
}

              | Empty

{

    else if v > value then Node(left, value, Insert(right, v))
    else t)

}

Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

  reads t

SCORE
-1.0
['}\n']
['  ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), lower, upper)\n']
['{\n']
['  // Base cases\n']
['  if t == Empty {\n']
['  } else {\n']
['    match t\n']
['    case Node(left, value, right) =>\n']
['      if v == value {\n']
['      } else if v < value {\n']
['        InsertPreservesBST(left, v, lower, value);\n']
['      } else {\n']
['        InsertPreservesBST(right, v, value, upper);\n']
['      }\n']
['  }\n']
['}\n']

  decreases tree

  case Node(l, v, r) =>

    v <= upper &&

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate to check if a tree is a BST
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  reads tree
  decreases tree
{
  match tree
  case Node(l, v, r) =>
    l == Empty || IsBST(l, lower, v) &&
    v <= upper &&
    r == Empty || IsBST(r, v, upper)

   |
12 |     l == Empty || IsBST(l, lower, v) &&
   |                                      ^^

   |
13 |     v <= upper &&
   |                ^^

   |                                     ^

  | Leaf
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

  case Leaf => true

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers

  | Leaf
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)

  case Leaf => true

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

  case Leaf => true

   |                                   ^

  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers

  | Leaf
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate to check if a tree is a BST
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, min: nat, max: nat) 
{
  match tree
  case Leaf => true
  case Node(left, value, right) => 
    value >= min && value <= max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value - 1) &&

   |                                 ^

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Leaf
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate to check if a tree is a BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
  reads t
  reads min, max
{
  match t
  case Leaf => true
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value >= min && value <= max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value - 1) &&
    IsBST(right, value + 1, max)
}

  |
8 |   reads t
  |         ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Leaf
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Write a predicate to check if a given tree is a binary search tree
function IsBST(tree: Tree, min: nat, max: nat): bool
{
  match tree
  case Leaf => true
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value >= min && value <= max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value - 1) &&

   |
13 |     IsBST(left, min, value - 1) &&
   |                                   ^

ex.dfy(13,34): Error: invalid UnaryExpression
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['    IsBST(left, min, value - 1) &&\n']
TEXT

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Leaf
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Write a predicate to check if a given tree is a binary search tree
function IsBST(tree: Tree, min: nat, max: nat): bool
{
  match tree
  case Leaf => true
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value >= min && value <= max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value - 1) &&
    IsBST(right, value + 1, max)

   |
14 |     IsBST(right, value + 1, max)
   |                                 ^

ex.dfy(14,32): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['    IsBST(right, value + 1, max)\n']
TEXT

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Leaf
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Write a predicate to check if a given tree is a binary search tree
function IsBST(tree: Tree, min: nat, max: nat): bool
{
  match tree
  case Leaf => true
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value >= min && value <= max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value - 1) &&
    IsBST(right, value + 1, max)
}

ex.dfy(13,27): Error: value does not satisfy the subset constraints of 'nat'
   |
13 |     IsBST(left, min, value - 1) &&
   |                            ^


Dafny program verifier finished with 0 verified, 1 error

SCORE
-1.0
['}\n']
['{\n']
['  match tree\n']
['  case Leaf => true\n']
['  case Node(left, value, right) =>\n']
['    value >= min && value <= max &&\n']
['    IsBST(left, min, value - 1) &&\n']
['    IsBST(right, value + 1, max)\n']
['}\n']

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)

SCORE
1.0
['predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)\n']

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  reads t
  requires lower <= upper
{
  match t
  case Leaf => true
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value >= lower &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(left, lower, value - 1) &&

   |                                     ^

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  reads t
  requires lower <= upper
{
  match t
  case Leaf => true
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value >= lower &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(left, lower, value - 1) &&
    IsBST(right, value + 1, upper)

   |
17 |     IsBST(right, value + 1, upper)
   |                                   ^

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
  reads t
  requires lower <= upper
{
  match t
  case Leaf => true
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value >= lower &&
    value <= upper &&
    IsBST(left, lower, value - 1) &&
    IsBST(right, value + 1, upper)
}

  |
8 |   reads t
  |         ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&

   |
13 |     value >= lower &&
   |                      ^

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
  reads tree
  reads value
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, nodeValue, right) =>
    if value < nodeValue then
      Node(Insert(left, value), nodeValue, right)

   |
26 |       Node(Insert(left, value), nodeValue, right)
   |                                                  ^

ex.dfy(26,49): Error: else expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['      Node(Insert(left, value), nodeValue, right)\n']
TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree

  reads tree
  reads value
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, nodeValue, right) =>
    if value < nodeValue then
      Node(Insert(left, value), nodeValue, right)
    else if value > nodeValue then

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

  requires true
  ensures IsBST(tree, Min_nat, Max_nat) && IsBST(result, Min_nat, Max_nat)

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
  requires true
  ensures IsBST(tree, Min_nat, Max_nat) && IsBST(result, Min_nat, Max_nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v {

   |

   |                  ^

  | Leaf

    value >= lower &&

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.

match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree

   |
27 |       else tree
   |                ^

  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v > value ? Contains(left, value) : Contains(right, value))

  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true

  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v > value ? Contains(left, value) : Contains(right, value))

datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || (v > value ? Contains(left, value) : Contains(right, value))
  case Leaf => false
}

   |
36 |     (v == value) || (v > value ? Contains(left, value) : Contains(right, value))
   |                                ^

ex.dfy(36,31): Error: closeparen expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
-1.0
['}\n']
['{\n']
['  match tree\n']
['  case Node(left, v, right) =>\n']

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.

Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{

   |
43 | {
   |  ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true

{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value <= 0 then
      assert Contains(tree, value);

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true

{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false

  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)

  // Proof by structural induction on the tree

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the structure of the tree.
  // Base case: if the tree is Leaf, then it's vacuously true that the new tree contains the value.

   |
45 |   // Base case: if the tree is Leaf, then it's vacuously true that the new tree contains the value.

case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the structure of the tree.
  // Base case: if the tree is Leaf, then it's vacuously true that the new tree contains the value.
  // Inductive case: if the tree is a Node, then the new tree contains the value if it's in the left subtree,

   |
46 |   // Inductive case: if the tree is a Node, then the new tree contains the value if it's in the left subtree,
   |                                                                                                              ^

ex.dfy(46,109): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
["  // Inductive case: if the tree is a Node, then the new tree contains the value if it's in the left subtree,\n"]

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).

Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the structure of the tree.
  // Base case: if the tree is Leaf, then it's vacuously true that the new tree contains the value.
  // Inductive case: if the tree is a Node, then the new tree contains the value if it's in the left subtree,
  // the right subtree, or at the root.

   |
47 |   // the right subtree, or at the root.
   |                                        ^

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on tree
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, value);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, value);

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on tree
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, value);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, value);
  case Leaf =>
}

ex.dfy(49,2): Error: a postcondition could not be proved on this return path

   |   ^^^^

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on tree
}

Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

{

      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on tree
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value <= 0 then
      // Base case: if value <= 0, then the tree is unchanged
      InsertEnsuresContains(tree, value)

   |                   ^

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree

{

    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by induction on tree
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, value);

   |

   |                                        ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by induction on tree
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    InsertEnsuresContains(left, value);
    InsertEnsuresContains(right, value);

   |
49 |     InsertEnsuresContains(right, value);
   |                                         ^

ex.dfy(49,40): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE

      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))

    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
}

    value >= lower &&

    case Node(left, v, right) =>

      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))

{

  case Node(left, v, right) =>

  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true

{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on tree
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value <= 0 then
      assert Contains(Insert(tree, value), value);

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on tree
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value <= 0 then
      assert Contains(Insert(tree, value), value);
    else

   |
47 |     if value <= 0 then
   |                   ^

ex.dfy(47,18): Error: lbrace expected
   |
49 |     else
   |     ^

ex.dfy(49,4): Error: this symbol not expected in CaseStmt
2 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
-1.0
['    else\n']
['{\n']
['  // Proof by structural induction on tree\n']
TEXT
