```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on tree
}

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

{

  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element

  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree

  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)

      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)

  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)

    if value <= 0 then
      // Base case: if value is less than or equal to 0, it is in the tree

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value <= 0 then
      // Base case: if value is less than or equal to 0, it is in the tree
      assert Contains(tree, value);

   |
47 |     if value <= 0 then
   |                   ^

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Base case: value is less than or equal to 0

   |
44 |   // Base case: value is less than or equal to 0
   |                                                 ^

Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Base case: value is less than or equal to 0
  if value <= 0 {

   |
45 |   if value <= 0 {
   |                  ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Base case: value is less than or equal to 0
  if value <= 0 {
  } else {
    // Recursive case: value is greater than 0
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, value);
      } else if value > v {
        InsertEnsuresContains(right, value);

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma about the insert function that ensures the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Base case: value is less than or equal to 0
  if value <= 0 {
  } else {
    // Recursive case: value is greater than 0
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, value);
      } else if value > v {
        InsertEnsuresContains(right, value);
      }

   |
54 |       }
   |        ^

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma for the Insert function that ensures the tree resulting from
// inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property)
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat, newTree: Tree)
{
  Contains(tree, value) <==> Contains(newTree, value)
}

   |
44 |   Contains(tree, value) <==> Contains(newTree, value)
   |                         ^

ex.dfy(44,24): Error: invalid UpdateStmt

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true

  else

    case Node(left, v, right) =>

      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)

```dafny

datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma for the Insert function that ensures the tree resulting from
// inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property)
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat, newTree: Tree)
requires Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
ensures Contains(newTree, value)
{
  // Base case: if the tree is a leaf, then the new tree is a node with the inserted value

   |
46 |   // Base case: if the tree is a leaf, then the new tree is a node with the inserted value
   |                                                                                           ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property)

  case Node(left, value, right) =>

datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma for the Insert function that ensures the tree resulting from
// inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property)
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat, newTree: Tree)
requires Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
ensures Contains(newTree, value)
{
  // Base case: if the value is in the tree, then it is in the new tree.
  // Inductive step: if the value is not in the tree, then it must be in either the left or the right subtree.

   |
47 |   // Inductive step: if the value is not in the tree, then it must be in either the left or the right subtree.
   |                                                                                                               ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

['  // Inductive step: if the value is not in the tree, then it must be in either the left or the right subtree.\n']

Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers

  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

{

  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)

      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma for the Insert function that ensures the tree resulting from
// inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property)
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat, newTree: Tree)
requires Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
ensures Contains(newTree, value)
{
  // Base case: value is in tree
  if tree == newTree {
  } else {
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, value, newTree);

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma for the Insert function that ensures the tree resulting from
// inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property)
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat, newTree: Tree)
requires Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
ensures Contains(newTree, value)
{
  // Base case: value is in tree
  if tree == newTree {
  } else {
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v {
        InsertEnsuresContains(left, value, newTree);
      } else if value > v {

   |
53 |       } else if value > v {
   |                            ^

      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))

}

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false

  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma for the Insert function that ensures the tree resulting from
// inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property)
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{

   |
44 | {
   |  ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.

Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma for the Insert function that ensures the tree resulting from
// inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property)
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on tree

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma for the Insert function that ensures the tree resulting from
// inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property)
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat, newTree: Tree)
  requires Insert(tree, value) == newTree

    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&

    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false

  requires Insert(tree, value) == newTree
  ensures Contains(newTree, value)

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.

Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

// (5) Define a lemma for the Insert function that ensures the tree resulting from
// inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property)
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(tree: Tree, value: nat, newTree: Tree)
  requires Insert(tree, value) == newTree
  ensures Contains(newTree, value)
{
  // Base case

   |
46 |   // Base case
   |               ^

  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
  | Leaf

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true

{

  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element

{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Leaf => false
}

  ensures Contains(Insert(tree, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on tree
}

  case Leaf => true

  | Leaf

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(tree: Tree, lower: nat, upper: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    IsBST(left, lower, value) &&
    value <= upper &&
    value >= lower &&
    IsBST(right, value, upper)
  case Leaf => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(tree: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  if value <= 0 then tree
  else
    match tree
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
      else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
      else tree
    case Leaf => Node(Leaf, value, Leaf)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a given tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(tree: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match tree
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) ||
    (value < v ? Contains(left, value) : Contains(right, value))
  case Leaf => false
}

   |
37 |     (value < v ? Contains(left, value) : Contains(right, value))
   |                ^

ex.dfy(37,15): Error: closeparen expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
-1.0
['}\n']
['\n']
TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.

### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2

  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (value < v ? Contains(left, value) :

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form

case Bar(x) => 2

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (value < v ? Contains(left, value) :
     value > v ? Contains(right, value) :

    else t

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree

{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || (value < v ? Contains(left, value) : Contains(right, value))

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || (value < v ? Contains(left, value) : Contains(right, value))
  case Empty => false

   |
32 |     (v == value) || (value < v ? Contains(left, value) : Contains(right, value))
   |                                ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || (value < v ? Contains(left, value) : Contains(right, value))
  case Empty => false
}

   |
32 |     (v == value) || (value < v ? Contains(left, value) : Contains(right, value))
   |                                ^

ex.dfy(32,31): Error: closeparen expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
-1.0
['}\n']
['\n']
['// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element\n']
['predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)\n']
['{\n']
['  match t\n']
['  case Node(left, v, right) =>\n']
['    value == v ? true\n']
TEXT

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    value == v ? true
    else if value < v then Contains(left, value)

   |
32 |     value == v ? true
   |                ^

// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers

              | Empty

predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true

    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)

{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    value == v ? true
    else if value < v then Contains(left, value)
    else Contains(right, value)

              | Empty

    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&

    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, value), value)
{

   |

   |  ^

}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, value), value)
{
}

// (6) Lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion

SCORE
1.0
['// (6) Lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion\n']
TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, value), value)
{
}

// (6) Lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesIsBST(t: Tree, value: nat, min: nat, max: nat)

              | Empty

    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)

{

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, value), value)
{
}

// (6) Lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesIsBST(t: Tree, value: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
requires IsBST(t, min, max)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, value), min, max)
{
}

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, value), value)
{
}

// (6) Lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesIsBST(t: Tree, value: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
requires IsBST(t, min, max)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, value), min, max)
{
}

Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).

case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)

    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t

}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element

{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, value), value)
{
}

// (6) Lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertPreservesIsBST(t: Tree, value: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
requires IsBST(t, min, max)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, value), min, max)
{
}
``` import { Component, OnInit, Input } from '@angular/core';

              | Empty

{

  case Empty => false

datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  // Base case: Empty tree
  if t == Empty {

   |
43 |   if t == Empty {
   |                  ^

Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.

{

    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)

    IsBST(right, value, max)

    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  // Base case: Empty tree
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    // Inductive step: Recursive call to lemma
    match t
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, value);
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, value);
  }
}

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.

Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  // Base case: Empty tree

  } else {
    // Inductive step: Recursive call to lemma
    match t
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, value);
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, value);
  }
}

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  // Base case: Empty tree
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    // Inductive step: Recursive call to lemma
    match t
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, value);
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, value);
  }
}

// (6) Lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsBST(t: Tree, value: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
requires IsBST(t, min, max)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, value), min, max)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  // Base case: Empty tree

  } else {

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  // Base case: Empty tree
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    // Inductive step: Recursive call to lemma
    match t
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, value);
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, value);
  }
}

// (6) Lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsBST(t: Tree, value: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
requires IsBST(t, min, max)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, value), min, max)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  // Base case: Empty tree
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    // Inductive step: Recursive call to lemma
    match t
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v {
        InsertMaintainsBST(left, value, min, v);
      } else if value > v {

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  // Base case: Empty tree
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    // Inductive step: Recursive call to lemma
    match t
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, value);
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, value);
  }
}

// (6) Lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsBST(t: Tree, value: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
requires IsBST(t, min, max)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, value), min, max)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  // Base case: Empty tree
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    // Inductive step: Recursive call to lemma
    match t
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v {
        InsertMaintainsBST(left, value, min, v);
      } else if value > v {
        InsertMaintainsBST(right, value, v, max);
      }

   |
69 |       }
   |        ^

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  // Base case: Empty tree
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    // Inductive step: Recursive call to lemma
    match t
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, value);
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, value);
  }
}

// (6) Lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion
lemma InsertMaintainsBST(t: Tree, value: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
requires IsBST(t, min, max)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, value), min, max)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  // Base case: Empty tree
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    // Inductive step: Recursive call to lemma
    match t
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      if value < v {
        InsertMaintainsBST(left, value, min, v);
      } else if value > v {
        InsertMaintainsBST(right, value, v, max);
      }
  }

{

    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

{

  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)

```dafny
// (1) Define an ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree = Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
              | Empty

// (2) Define a predicate for checking if a tree is a binary search tree
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value > min && value < max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value) &&
    IsBST(right, value, max)
  case Empty => true
}

// (3) Define a function for inserting an element into a binary search tree
function Insert(t: Tree, value: nat): Tree
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    if value < v then Node(Insert(left, value), v, right)
    else if value > v then Node(left, v, Insert(right, value))
    else t
  case Empty => Node(Empty, value, Empty)
}

// (4) Define a predicate for checking if a tree contains a given element
predicate Contains(t: Tree, value: nat)
{
  match t
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    (v == value) || Contains(left, value) || Contains(right, value)
  case Empty => false
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element
lemma InsertEnsuresContains(t: Tree, value: nat)
requires true
ensures Contains(Insert(t, value), value)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the tree
  // Base case: Empty tree
  if t == Empty {
  } else {
    // Inductive step: Recursive call to lemma
    match t
    case Node(left, v, right) =>
      InsertEnsuresContains(left, value);
      InsertEnsuresContains(right, value);
  }
}

// (6) Lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion

requires IsBST(t, min, max)
ensures IsBST(Insert(t, value), min, max)

      InsertMaintainsBST(right, value, v, max);
